objects.author: Megan Banta
objects.title: After 342 new COVID-19 cases in 3 weeks, Michigan State students urged to self-quarantine
objects.html:
EAST LANSING – Health officials are strongly recommending Michigan State University students living in or near East Lansing self-quarantine immediately following a surge in COVID-19 cases.

At least 342 people affiliated with the university have tested positive for the disease caused by the novel coronavirus since Aug. 24, according to the Ingham County Health Department.

Nearly all of those people are students, according to health department spokeswoman Amanda Darche.

That's compared to just 23 people affiliated with MSU testing positive in the three weeks before the surge, according to a press release from the department.

The uptick in cases began as students returned to East Lansing and the surrounding communities for the fall semester.

According to the health department, at least a third of people who tested positive recently attended parties or social gatherings, and at least one third of those gatherings were associated with a fraternity or sorority.

Following the surge, the department "strongly recommends all local MSU students self-quarantine immediately to contain the outbreak," the release states. Self-quarantine should last until 11:59 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 26.

Darche clarified that means students living on or near campus.

According to the university, about 1,200 students are living in on-campus apartments and fewer than 2,000 students are living in dorms.

Officials don't have an estimate for how many students are living in and around East Lansing.

The recommendation is not an emergency order, but "more stringent and mandatory restrictions will be imposed if students do not comply and break the transmission cycle." That could include an emergency order, Darche said.

Ingham County Health Officer Linda Vail said the situation is urgent and the "exponential growth" of cases needs to stop.

Pick the LSJ high school athlete of the week winner for Sept. 21-26 Lawsuit: Grand Ledge Board of Education violated the law during June meeting Records: Man charged in fatal crash violates bond after judge lowers it Lawsuit: Mason gun store's negligence led to murder of Charlotte woman As MSU-related COVID-19 cases drop quickly, health official worried some aren't testing

"I am concerned about the health and safety of the MSU community, and importantly, I am seriously concerned that unchecked transmission locally will affect the health and safety of all Ingham County residents," Vail said in a statement. "If we do not slow the spread immediately, we will be dealing with the consequences across the county for months to come."

Students in quarantine should remain at home for the next two weeks other than to attend in-person classes, labs and athletic practices. They also may leave their homes to work or to get food, medicine, medical care, or necessary supplies when delivery is not an option.

MSU physician David Weismantel said the school is "committed to doing everything we can to prevent the spread of COVID-19."

That includes closing portions of dining services during the self-quarantine period.

According to a Facebook post from MSU Culinary Services, the food court and all seating areas within campus dining locations are closed indefinitely, and Sparty's Market closed at 5 p.m. Saturday. There is no official reopening date.

"All of us are responsible not only for our own health but also for that of the community, especially its most vulnerable members," a Saturday letter from Weismantel to the campus community reads.

Weismantel stresses in the letter that actions now will "significantly influence decisions on how much of the spring semester will be conducted in person or remotely."

He also reminded people the university's community compact applies to off-campus behavior and "compliance with community health directives."

The university already is considering interim suspensions for a number of students who have repeatedly violated the community impact by ignoring safety mandates.

East Lansing Mayor Aaron Stephens and other city officials are "urging students to understand the imperative role that they play in stopping this community spread and, ultimately, saving lives."

"While we know many students are doing the right thing, we are still seeing far too many social gatherings in the off-campus community, where individuals are in close contact without face coverings," Stephens said in a statement.

"This person-to-person contact is the main way that the virus spreads and has contributed significantly to the recent spike in student cases."

The health department is working to evaluate congregate settings, including houses licensed for more than 10 unrelated people, to see if officials need to do more, according to the release.

Contact reporter Megan Banta at mbanta@lsj.com. Follow her on Twitter @MeganBanta_1.

Nearly all of those people are students, according to health department spokeswoman Amanda Darche.
That's compared to just 23 people affiliated with MSU testing positive in the three weeks before the surge, according to a press release from the department.
The uptick in cases began as students returned to East Lansing and the surrounding communities for the fall semester.
According to the health department, at least a third of people who tested positive recently attended parties or social gatherings, and at least one third of those gatherings were associated with a fraternity or sorority.
Following the surge, the department "strongly recommends all local MSU students self-quarantine immediately to contain the outbreak," the release states. Self-quarantine should last until 11:59 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 26.
Darche clarified that means students living on or near campus.
According to the university, about 1,200 students are living in on-campus apartments and fewer than 2,000 students are living in dorms.
Officials don't have an estimate for how many students are living in and around East Lansing.
